contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox Former Subdivision |conventional_long_name =Southern Tagalog |native_name = ''Timog Katagalugan'' |common_name = Southern Tagalog |nation = Philippines |status_text = Former Region of the [[Philippines]] |era = |year_start = |date_start = |event_start= |date_end = May 17, 2002 |year_end = 2002 |life_span= |p1 = |flag_p1 = |s1 = |flag_s1 = |s2 = |flag_s2 = |image_flag = |image_coat = |image_map = Ph locator map southern tagalog.PNG |image_map_caption = Map of the Philippines<br>Southern Tagalog shown in red |stat_area1 = |stat_year1 = |stat_pop1 = |footnotes = |capital = [[Metro Manila]] |today = [[CALABARZON|Region IV-A]] and [[MIMAROPA|Region IV-B]] }} '''Southern Tagalog''', or '''Region IV''', (Tagalog: ''Timog Katagalugan'') was a [[Regions of the Philippines|region]] of the [[Philippines]] that comprised what are now [[CALABARZON|Region IV-A (CALABARZON)]] and [[MIMAROPA|Region IV-B (MIMAROPA)]]. Region IV was [[Partition (politics)|partitioned]] into the two regions on May 17, 2002. ==History== ===Prior history and partition=== Southern Tagalog was the largest region in terms of both area and population. It comprised the [[Provinces of the Philippines|provinces]] of [[Aurora (province)|Aurora]] (now part of [[Central Luzon]]), [[Batangas]], [[Cavite]], [[Laguna (province)|Laguna]], [[Marinduque]], [[Oriental Mindoro]], [[Occidental Mindoro]], [[Quezon]], [[Rizal]], [[Romblon]], and [[Palawan]]. [[Quezon City]] was the designated regional centre of Southern Tagalog. The former region covered the area where many [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]] speakers reside; the two other majority-Tagalophone regions are the [[National Capital Region]] and [[Central Luzon]]. By virtue Executive Order No. 103, dated May 17, 2002, Region IV was divided into Region IV-A ('''[[CALABARZON]]''') and Region IV-B ('''[[MIMAROPA]]'''). ===Transfer of Palawan=== Palawan was transferred to Region VI ([[Western Visayas]]) on May 23, 2005 by virtue of Executive Order 429. However, PalaweÃ±os criticised the move citing a lack of public consultation. Most residents of [[Puerto Princesa]] and all but one of the province's munipalities preferred to stay in Region IV-B.<ref name="EO429">[http://www.nscb.gov.ph/activestats/psgc/articles/intro_EO429.asp "Executive Order no. 429"]. National Statistical Coordination Board. Retrieved on 2010-03-22.</ref> Consequently, Administrative Order No. 129 was issued on August 19, 2005 to address this backlash directing the abeyance of Executive Order 429, pending the approval of an implementation plan for the orderly transfer of Palawan from MIMAROPA to Region VI. Presently, Palawan is still considered part of MIMAROPA.<ref>[http://www.nscb.gov.ph/activestats/psgc/articles/admin_order_no_129.asp "Administrative Order no. 129"]. National Statistical Coordination Board.
